Graphical abstract Iron-based catalysts are frequently used in the Fischer-Tropsch reaction (FTR). The catalyst undergoes several phase changes during activation and catalytic reaction. Therefore, the activation and reduction conditions are crucial for the overall activity of the catalyst. The reduction of hematite with hydrogen was investigated by inverse temperature programmed reduction. Reduction proceeds either via the sequence Fe2O3 → Fe3O4 → α-Fe or, above 570 °C, via Fe2O3 → Fe3O4 → FeO → α-Fe. A quantitative approach for the individual reduction steps was proposed. Combining temperature ramps and isothermal ranges, the phase composition was investigated and correlated with catalytic results in the initial phase of FTR. For this, a hematite precursor was activated at different temperatures and applied as a catalyst for the FTR. An influence of activation temperature on the water gas shift activity and chain length of the formed hydrocarbons was observed. The formation of carbon dioxide as a product of the water gas shift reaction, was correlated with the presence of magnetite. Interestingly, hematite treated at temperatures below the temperature at which the formation of magnetite was expected, was already active in the FTR. Keywords Fischer-Tropsch Inverse temperature programmed reduction Reduction of hematite Active iron phase Catalyst activation 1 Introduction Recently, research into the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis has regained attention, since, with this technique, hydrogen and carbon monoxide can be converted to hydrocarbons. Therefore, the Fischer-Tropsch reaction (FTR) is a potential solution for hydrogen storage in the upcoming hydrogen-based energy supply [1,2]. In recent years, biomass [3] as well as waste [4] were discussed as raw materials for syngas synthesis, making FTR an ecologically friendly alternative to crude oil [2,5]. Reaction products are paraffins, olefins and oxygenated compounds of different chain lengths [6,7]. These could be utilized in the transport sector, with the advantage that the Fischer-Tropsch products are free of sulphur, nitrogen and aromatics [7–9]. Moreover, light olefins are valuable platform chemicals [7,10]. F. Fischer and H. Tropsch found that iron and cobalt are the most active catalysts in the reaction named after them [11]. Both iron and cobalt are commonly used in industry and research today [1,7]. The iron-based catalyst has different advantages compared to cobalt, such as a higher olefin selectivity [10]. Additionally, the H2 to CO ratio is more variable, since the Fe3O4 phase catalyses the water gas shift reaction (WGSR) in which H2 can be regained from the process water formed in the FTR [1,10,12–14]. Therefore, lower H2 concentrations in the feed are possible. Before using it for FTR, the iron-based catalyst has to be activated. Usually, iron (III) oxide is the catalyst precursor, which is then reduced under different conditions. Parameters of the activation process are e.g. activation atmosphere [15–18], pressure [19] and temperature [16]. The activation conditions have a significant impact on the iron phases formed and the activity [15,20,21]. The influence of the activation atmosphere has been investigated by several researchers. Chang et al. [22] found that in a hydrogen atmosphere, Fe2O3 (hematite) is reduced to α-Fe with Fe3O4 (magnetite) and FeO (wüstite) as intermediate phases formed during the reduction process. Pineau et al. [23] confirmed this reduction sequence. Furthermore, comparing the reducing agent carbon monoxide and hydrogen, they could show that the reduction rate is higher for the latter. Applying Mössbauer spectroscopy, it was shown, that an increase in the flow rate of hydrogen raises the reduction rate. The same trend was found for decreasing particle sizes [24]. When hematite was exposed to syngas (CO:H2 = 1:2) or carbon monoxide during activation, iron carbide (Fe7C3) was the dominating phase. Because the presence of water inhibits the formation of carbide, syngas forms less carbide compared to carbon monoxide [15–18,20,25]. In contrast, Mondal et al. [26] have shown, that in carbon monoxide atmosphere at temperatures of 800 °C hematite is reduced to α-Fe without the formation of carbides. The formation of the active phase during the activation process and its transformation under reaction conditions has been investigated by in-situ X-ray adsorption spectroscopy [17,22]. Carbides, formed from α-Fe, are assumed to be the active phase in the FTR. If those are not formed during the activation process, e.g. with carbon monoxide, they will be formed under reaction conditions at the start of the reaction. Different iron oxides and carbides are formed during the reaction. Therefore, the impact of the activation conditions on the long-time activity is low [27]. In literature, arbitrarily chosen activation conditions are reported, making the comparison of the results especially difficult. Furthermore, a systematic correlation between activation temperature and catalyst activity has not yet been reported. The activation conditions have a significant impact on the formed iron phases and, thus, on the activity in FTR [15,20,21]. The present work is therefore focussed on the influence of the activation temperature on the iron phase formed and its influence on activity and product distribution in the initial phase of FTR. Applying the improved sensitivity of the method of inverse temperature programmed reduction (iTPR), a more detailed insight on the mechanism of reduction of iron oxides will be given and correlated with the activity in the initial phase of FTR. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of hematite The bulk iron oxide was synthesized by the precipitation method. A 1 M solution of iron (III) nitrate (Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O, Sigma-Aldrich, ≥ 98 %) and a 5 wt. % aqueous solution of ammonia were heated separately to 70 °C. The ammonia solution was added slowly to the iron nitrate solution until a pH = 7 was obtained. The precipitate was filtered off and washed with deionised water. This iron hydroxide precipitate was dried and calcined at 400 °C for 4 h to obtain hematite. 2.2 Inverse temperature programmed reduction The reduction profile of the iron oxide catalyst was investigated by inverse temperature programmed reduction (iTPR). Compared to a classical temperature programmed reduction (TPR), the method allows one to quantify hydrogen, after its conversion into methane, by applying a flame ionisation detector (FID). Therefore, reduction peaks appear as negative peaks in the reduction profile. The principle of the method was described previously by Thomé et al. [28]. The system was calibrated by multiple dosage of a certain amount of hydrogen (250 μL) via the sample loop of a six-port valve. The degree of reduction was calculated by the amount of hydrogen consumed according to the stoichiometric reactions. The standard measurement was carried out with 50 mg of the calcined iron oxide and a heating rate of 10 °C/min between 30 °C and 1050 °C in 5 % H2 in N2 (50 mL/min), if not indicated otherwise. 2.3 X-ray diffraction X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out with fine powder samples. Samples were analysed in reflection mode in a PANalytical Empyrean in the range 2Θ = 10° - 80°. Cu Kα radiation was used from an X-ray tube operated with a voltage of 40 kV and a current of 40 mA. The divergence slit was 0.125° and the soller slit 0.5°. To avoid influences of the sample orientation, the sample holder was continuously rotated during the measurement. The scattered radiation was analysed using a PIXcel1D-Medipix3 detector. 2.4 Catalytic experiments Catalytic activity of the catalysts was tested in a reaction unit consisting of gas supply, stainless steel reactor and on-line gas analysis (Fig. 1 ). Mass controllers (Bronkhorst B.V.) controlled the flows of hydrogen (Air liquid, 99.999 %), carbon monoxide (Air liquid, 99.5 %) and nitrogen (Air liquid, 99.999 %). The mixture of these gases was directed over a four-port valve to the reactor. High boiling compounds are collected in a hot trap (T = 100 °C) after the reactor to prevent condensation in the tubes. Argon (Unterbichler Gase, GmbH, 99.996 %) was used as a balance gas which kept the pressure constant. A throttle valve controlled the pressure in the reactor. The different reaction products were analysed on a multi-channel Agilent 7890A GC equipped with 3 columns. At the first column, (CP-Molsieve 5 Å, 25 m x0.53 mm) H2, CO and Ar were separated, while at the second column (PoraPLOT Q-HT, 27.5 m x0.53 mm) the light gases and on the third column (DB-5, 30 m x0.32 mm) all hydrocarbons were separated. Because of the reduction of volume during the reaction, it was necessary to use an internal standard. For each catalytic run, 300 mg of Fe2O3 was mixed with 200 mg SiO2 to dilute the catalyst and prevent hot spots in the catalyst bed. Before the measurement, the catalyst was activated in a flow of hydrogen (volumetric flow 20 mL/min). Each experiment was operated at a different activation temperature for 12 h. The feed consisted of an equimolar ratio of hydrogen and carbon monoxide (H2:CO:N2 = 1:1:0.5). If not stated differently, the reaction temperature was 300 °C and the reaction pressure 3.5 bar. The conversion and selectivity were calculated from the peak area (A) of the compounds in the gas chromatogram. For the calculation of the conversion the peak area had to be corrected by the internal standard (Eq. 1). (1) X i = 100 % ∙ 1 - A i A i , b ∙ A I S , b A I S where A i is the peak area of the educt i; A i,b is the initial peak area of the educt i; AIS is the peak area of the internal standard; and A IS,b is the initial peak area of the internal standard. The selectivity of the organic compounds corresponds to the peak area fraction, detected by FID after the third column and corrected using the response factors and the carbon number of each identified compound [29,30]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterisation and reduction behaviour of the iron-based catalyst The as-synthesized iron-based catalyst was investigated by X-ray diffraction (Fig. 2 ). The reflexes obtained are in good agreement with literature data for Fe2O3 [31]. Typical reflexes are at 2Θ = 24.1° [110], 33.2° [104], 35.6° [110], 40.9° [113], 49.5° [024], and 54.1° [116]. Other phases were not detected. Typically, the iron catalyst is reduced before the Fischer-Tropsch reaction. Under reaction conditions, the catalytically active phase will be formed. The determination of the active iron phase for the Fischer-Tropsch reaction is still under discussion. In all likelihood, an iron carbide phase is formed from α-Fe, which accounts for the activity of the iron-based system. The reduction to α-Fe by this mechanism is a crucial point during the catalyst pre-treatment. Therefore, hematite should be reduced completely to α-Fe in the present hydrogen during the activation process [20,21]. Fe2O3 was investigated by inverse temperature programmed reduction to get a closer insight on the reduction behaviour of the iron catalyst. The iTPR profile of the as synthesized Fe2O3 sample shows three reduction steps (see Fig. 3 ). The first peak has a maximum at 360 °C. The second signal extends over a temperature range of 300 °C, starting from 380 °C with a maximum at 610 °C and a shoulder at the high temperature side of the peak (around 680 °C). A third small, asymmetric peak starts at 800 °C. This corresponds to reaction Scheme 1 . The first peak is related to the reduction from hematite to magnetite. It can be seen that the broad signal from 380 to 680 °C results from two overlapping reduction steps. This phenomenon is described in literature as the direct reduction of magnetite to α-Fe and the concurrent reduction of magnetite to wüstite (FeO) [20,32–34]. At higher temperatures, the wüstite phase is then reduced to α-Fe (at around 900 °C). In a first approach, deconvolution of the iTPR profile using Gaussian curves (Fig. 4 ) allowed separation of the reduction profile into differentiated reduction steps in line with reaction Scheme 1. The dashed line represents the reduction of hematite to magnetite (step I), whereas the dotted line is assigned to the reduction of magnetite to iron (step II) and the short dashes represent the formation of wüstite from magnetite (step III). The peak associated with the reduction of wüstite was not deconvoluted in Fig. 4. Applying in-situ XRD, Niu et al. [20] could show a similar sequence of reduction steps. Interestingly, they showed that α-Fe emerges at 490 °C. As seen in Fig. 4, the corresponding peak (dotted line) in iTPR profile started to rise at around 250 °C, which results in the presence of α-Fe at lower temperatures than described by Niu and co-workers [20]. The formation of wüstite (step III) started at a temperature of 570 °C and had a maximum at 670 °C, which agrees with literature data regarding the stability of FeO [32,34–36]. The reduction of wüstite to α-Fe started above 800 °C. The experimentally determined ratio of the paths III to IV is far from the theoretical value of 1:3 for the complete reduction of wüstite. According to thermodynamic calculation, wüstite is stable under the given conditions [35]. Therefore, its further reduction is inhibited. Note, that the Gaussian fit may not be the ideal graphical method to describe TPR-peaks and thus a certain error must be considered. According to Fig. 5 , the reduction path strongly depends on the heating rate. At a heating rate of 1 °C/min only two peaks appeared (step I and II). Therefore, the Fe3O4 formed should be reduced completely to α-Fe. The reduction process is completed below 550 °C [32]. Two tendencies were observed with increasing heating rate: (i) Instead of a two stage, a three-stage reduction took place. (ii) The maxima of the reduction peaks (with the exception of step IV) shifted to higher temperatures. Analogous tendencies were observed in the case of reduction of various sample sizes of Fe2O3 (Fig. 6 ). For amounts less than 20 mg, the two-stage reduction takes place, i.e. wüstite is not formed. Furthermore, the maximum of the reduction rate of magnetite shifts to higher temperatures with increasing sample size. When the temperature is higher than 580 °C, the two-step reduction path changes into a three-step one, i.e. magnetite is reduced to wüstite in parallel (step III). According to Table 1 , the ratio of reactions III:II increases, i.e. at higher sample amounts the formation of wüstite is preferred. A similar trend is found for the different heating rates. Obviously, the ratio of water to hydrogen at the catalyst surface plays a dominating role. Taking into account the phase composition when evaluating the dependence on the water to hydrogen ratio (Fig. 7 ), the situation is as follows: the lower the partial pressure of water in the temperature range between 250–300 °C (line a), the higher the probability that magnetite is reduced to α-Fe (line b’). When sufficient water is present, it acts as “oxidizing compound”, i.e. FeO is formed (line b’’) [33,37]. With these terms in mind, the data of Fig. 6 can be explained. The reduction of low amounts of magnetite forms a low amount of water, i.e. log(p(H2O)/p(H2)) < -0.5 and therefore, directs the reduction towards α-Fe. By comparison, at low heating rates the reduction is given more time and, thus, the carrier gas is able to remove more water from the surface, decreasing its partial pressure. This explains the apparent dependency on the heating rate in Fig. 5. Van Steen et al. [38] described a re-oxidation of nanoparticles by water, which is also influenced by the H2O:H2 ratio. A re-oxidation during the measurement might occur, but does not influence the quantification in the present study. In addition, the reduction is a kinetically controlled process. At small sample sizes and low heating rates, the reduction of magnetite starts at lower temperatures compared to the temperatures at which the signal arises at high samples sizes/heating rates. As it can be seen from the deconvolution of the peaks in Fig. 4, the reduction of magnetite had already started before the hematite reduction was completed, resulting in an overlap of the two peaks, which was more pronounced at high samples sizes/heating rates. The rate limitation, which is temperature dependant, might be another explanation for the favoured formation of wüstite at high sample sizes or heating rates. Comparing the integral of the peaks, which is proportional to the number of transferred electrons, a ratio of the peak areas I:II = 2:16 for the complete reduction of magnetite formed is expected. As the data given in Table 1 confirms, the ratio decreases with increasing sample size. The degree of reduction for hematite is independent on the sample size and close to one. This is consistent with in-situ XRD measurements in literature, which showed that hematite is completely reduced at temperatures above 350 °C [20]. Both the degree of reduction and the ratio of peak areas (II:I) indicates that the magnetite reduction is hindered with higher sample sizes. Moreover, the formation of wüstite lowers the overall degree of reduction since the reduction of wüstite is more challenging. In addition, the ratio of II:I decreases with the formation of wüstite since part of the magnetite is not directly reduced to α-Fe. Therefore, this fraction is not included in the integral corresponding to reaction step II. Differences between calculated and expected data could be caused by the overlapping of the reduction of hematite to magnetite and magnetite to α-Fe. Furthermore, limitation by diffusion of hydrogen through the iron shell of partially reduced oxide cannot be excluded [34]. From these results the question arises as to which the lowest temperature is, that is necessary for complete reduction of hematite to α-Fe. Since the reduction is a kinetically controlled process, stop-experiments were conducted to solve this question. During these stop-experiments, the temperature programmed heating of the samples was stopped at a defined temperature and the hydrogen consumption was recorded under isothermal conditions for 2 h. Afterwards, the heating program was resumed. In Fig. 8 , the temperature ramp was stopped at 350 °C. Note that due to the thermal inertia of the reactor, no sharp kink in the temperature curve could be expected. In the isothermal range, a deviation from the baseline was observed, i.e. the reduction of magnetite to α-Fe seemed to start immediately after its formation (see also Fig. 4). With rising temperature, a well-pronounced peak for path II appeared. At this early stage, control of the water to hydrogen ratio understandably determines the direction of reduction. In the given experiment, the carrier gas keeps the partial pressure of water very low, favouring the reduction to α-Fe (see Fig. 7). Nevertheless, the major part of magnetite is reduced at temperatures above the isothermal range at 350 °C. The ratio of intensities of paths II:I = 6.6, which is still lower than the theoretical value of eight, meaning that not all magnetite was reduced directly to α-Fe. For this reason, the experiment was repeated with an isothermal range at 400 °C (Fig. 9 ). It can be seen that the integral of the isothermal range increases and the integral of the reduction peak at higher temperatures decreases. Nevertheless, the ratio of the integrals of both peaks is 7.2 and higher as in the previous experiment (Table 1). It is noteworthy that, despite a heating rate of 10 °C/min, the reduction of magnetite results almost entirely in α-Fe. The reduction peak of wüstite is hardly detected. A further increase of the hold temperature to 530 °C lead to a reduction profile with two peaks (Fig. 10 ). The reduction of magnetite was finished after roughly 1 h at the isothermal temperature. No formation of wüstite was observed since the reduction was completed below 570 °C. Considering that the ratio of both peaks (7.6) is close to the theoretical value of eight, a complete reduction of the formed magnetite can be concluded. The overall degree of reduction, i.e. ratio of reduced to unreduced iron, was calculated (see experimental section). Higher isothermal temperatures increased the degree of reduction from 0.63 (350 °C) to 0.66 (400 °C) and 0.69 (530 °C), respectively. According to Table 1, the degree of reduction of hematite to magnetite does not equal 1, i.e. hematite remains partially unreduced. In addition, the overall degree of reduction is always smaller than that of hematite (step I), indicating that the magnetite formed is also not completely reduced. Furthermore, the position of the maximum of the reduction peak of magnetite depends not only on the heating rate (Fig. 5) but also on the kind of heating ramp, here with an isothermal range at different temperatures. This underlines the typical properties of kinetically controlled methods like temperature programmed reduction. Consequently, the duration of isothermal treatment should influence the reduction behaviour. However, this was not the subject of the present study. Summarizing the results of the iTPR, the following recommendations for the reduction of precursor Fe2O3 to catalytically active iron can be made: (i) The ratio of the partial pressure of water to hydrogen must be carefully controlled by choosing a slow heating rate. The same effect could be expected with an increase of the flow rate. (ii) Formation of wüstite must be avoided since its reduction requires very high temperatures. The wüstite formation is suppressed when magnetite is completely reduced at 530 °C. (iii) Application of longer isothermal periods favours the reduction at lower temperatures as determined by temperature programmed reduction. 3.2 Catalytic data For the Fischer-Tropsch reaction, different activation temperatures were chosen in order to investigate the influence of different iron species on the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. The Fe2O3 catalyst was reduced at 250, 300, 350 or 400 °C. From iTPR data, it can be seen that at an activation temperature of 250 °C the overall degree of reduction is very low. The formation of magnetite can’t be excluded due to the start of hematite reduction around 250 °C and the long isothermal period of 12 h (see Fig. 3). At 300 °C magnetite is expected to be the dominating phase and at an activation temperature higher than 300 °C the resulting phase should be α-Fe. Since a lower heating rate and a long activation time at constant temperature was chosen, an activation temperature of 350 °C should be sufficient to obtain a complete reduction of the catalyst (compare to Fig. 8). The formation of wüstite can be excluded at any activation temperature tested, as wüstite is not formed below a temperature of 570 °C. Table 2 summarizes the composition of the catalyst after the activation. During the catalytic reaction carbidization of the iron will occur. Note, that it is not possible to distinguish whether the carbidization starts from the α-Fe or iron oxide species. The catalytic data obtained at a reaction temperature of 300 °C are presented in Fig. 11 . Comparing the initial activities, the lines could be separated into two groups: (i) catalysts reduced at temperatures above 300 °C, and (ii) catalysts treated at below or equal to 300 °C. The first group has a higher initial activity and deactivates rapidly, whereas the activity loss is less pronounced for the second group. Consequently, the active centres responsible for the high activity at the beginning must be formed during the formation of iron. The high initial CO conversion might be explained by the formation of iron carbides, which is facilitated at iron (0) surface sites as opposed to iron oxides. Note, that the reduction and reaction temperatures were identical for the catalysts reduced at 250 °C (dashed line). After 160 min time on stream (TOS) the reaction temperature was increased to 300 °C (solid line). By raising the reaction temperature, the CO conversion initially increased rapidly, but again approached the value of the reaction at 250 °C after 1 h. In Fig. 12 the conversion of carbon monoxide and hydrogen are compared with respect to their dependence on the activation temperature. The highest activity was found for the activation temperature of 250 °C. Increasing the activation temperature to 300 °C decreases the conversion of both carbon monoxide and hydrogen. A further increase of the activation temperature resulted in a slight increase in the conversion of CO and H2. Interestingly, the increase in reaction temperature for the catalyst activated at 250 °C decreases the conversion and brings it closer to the values of the catalyst activated at 300 °C. Under reaction conditions, reducing agents like hydrogen are present. Thus, the incomplete reduction might be driven forward by the increase in temperature. Nevertheless, at an activation temperature of 300 °C α-Fe has not been formed, resulting in a lower activity compared to the activity of the catalyst reduced at higher temperatures. It is necessary to consider the formation of carbon dioxide via the water gas shift reaction (WGSR, Scheme 2 ). According to Fig. 3, Fe3O4 is present in the catalyst after the activation at 300 °C. It is known [12–14] that Fe3O4 is an excellent catalyst for the WGSR. Increasing the activation temperature from 300 to 400 °C, the selectivity to carbon dioxide drops from 19.5 % to 8.8 %. Consequently, the reduction degree of the catalyst must be increased (magnetite concentration has to be decreased) to avoid the formation of carbon dioxide. It is noteworthy that when both activation and reaction temperature are 250 °C, the lowest selectivity to carbon dioxide was observed (4.8 %). This value did not change during a reaction time of 2.5 h, suggesting that this activation temperature was not high enough to form magnetite. Clearly, hematite is not active for the WGSR but catalyses the FTR. However, it may be converted to iron carbide, which is catalytically active in the FTR. Evidently, both the reaction and reduction temperatures play a significant role for WGSR [12].A significant influence of the activation temperature on the selectivity of the hydrocarbons could not be observed (see Fig. 13 ). The selectivity to C2+ hydrocarbons increases slightly with the activation temperature, whereas the methane selectivity decreases, due to the presence of α-Fe at activation temperatures higher than 300 °C. Selectivity data obtained at a reaction temperature of 250 °C differed from the data obtained at 300 °C. Generally, lower reaction temperatures increase the chain growth probability. This is in agreement with literature [1,6,7,10]. At an activation temperature of 300 °C, the selectivity to olefins reached the highest value. Olefins are primary products of the reaction. Paraffins are formed through hydrogenation in a secondary reaction. Since at an activation temperature of 300 °C both the CO2 and olefin selectivity are the highest, the hydrogenation activity of the magnetite phase is the lowest. However, interpretation in terms of a network of sequential reaction seems to be more likely than a straight correlation with the phase composition. 4 Conclusion Using the higher sensitivity of inverse temperature programmed reduction, the reduction behaviour of iron oxide (hematite) was studied and correlated with the catalytic activity in the Fischer-Tropsch reaction. The reduction profiles made it possible to assign the peaks to the sequence Fe2O3 → Fe3O4 → α-Fe/FeO → α-Fe. The formation of FeO (wüstite) strongly depends on the ratio of the partial pressures of hydrogen and water as well as the reduction temperature. Both heating rate and sample size influenced this ratio. Stop-experiments at different temperatures can also retard the formation of FeO. This has consequences when choosing optimal activation parameters. Under the applied FTR conditions, Fe3O4 favours the formation of carbon dioxide via the water gas shift reaction. With increasing activation temperature, accompanied by further reduction of the catalyst by hydrogen and carbon monoxide, formation of hydrocarbons increased at the expense of carbon dioxide. Catalysts activated at 350 °C or higher showed high initial activities. Differences to the catalysts activated at lower temperatures were equalised after a certain reaction time. Interestingly, hematite, even though it was not reduced, is active for the FTR. A further reduction or carbidization of the catalyst by feed components cannot be excluded. coredata.dc:description: Iron-based catalysts are frequently used in the Fischer-Tropsch reaction (FTR). The catalyst undergoes several phase changes during activation and catalytic reaction. Therefore, the activation and reduction conditions are crucial for the overall activity of the catalyst. The reduction of hematite with hydrogen was investigated by inverse temperature programmed reduction. Reduction proceeds either via the sequence Fe2O3 → Fe3O4 → α-Fe or, above 570 °C, via Fe2O3 → Fe3O4 → FeO → α-Fe. A quantitative approach for the individual reduction steps was proposed. Combining temperature ramps and isothermal ranges, the phase composition was investigated and correlated with catalytic results in the initial phase of FTR. For this, a hematite precursor was activated at different temperatures and applied as a catalyst for the FTR. An influence of activation temperature on the water gas shift activity and chain length of the formed hydrocarbons was observed. The formation of carbon dioxide as a product of the water gas shift reaction, was correlated with the presence of magnetite. Interestingly, hematite treated at temperatures below the temperature at which the formation of magnetite was expected, was already active in the FTR.
coredata.dc:title: Quantitative study of the oxidation state of iron-based catalysts by inverse temperature-programmed reduction and its consequences for catalyst activation and performance in Fischer-Tropsch reaction
